Introduction_Scene.Speaker: Narrator
Introduction_Scene.Dialogue: You find yourself in your bedroom, waking up from the inky darkness of sleep. It's relatively early, and you can hear your mum calling you from somewhere in the house.

Introduction_Scene.Speaker: Mum
Introduction_Scene.Dialogue: {0}, wake up! It's getting late and we have stuff to do!

Introduction_Scene.Speaker: Mum
Introduction_Scene.Dialogue: I mean it, {0}! Don't make me come in with the bucket of water!
I suppose I better get up...

Introduction_Scene.Speaker: Narrator
Introduction_Scene.Dialogue: Your limbs feel like lead, as you roll out of bed, studying the surroundings you called home.

Introduction_Scene.Speaker: Narrator
Introduction_Scene.Dialogue: When you see a circle like this, this is something you can click. This can either be to get a better view, something you can interact with, or something to progress the scene. Try clicking on it now.

Controls.Speaker: Narrator
Controls.Dialogue: Using the arrows on your screen, or by using WASD, you can move around the room and interact with things. Some rooms will allow you to look up, in which case your screen will look like this.

Controls.Speaker: Narrator
Controls.Dialogue: You can see the up and down arrows have now appeared. In this scene, you won't have to worry about looking up and down, so I will turn them off again.

Controls.Speaker: Narrator
Controls.Dialogue: Similarly to before, anywhere you can see a circle-like object, this is something you can interact with. Try interacting with the wardrobe.

Controls.Speaker: Narrator
Controls.Dialogue: There we go. Any time during the game, if you would like to see the source of any information provided, such as a fact, you can press the 'K' key.

Controls.Speaker: Narrator
Controls.Dialogue: This will show a list of sources that the information was obtained from. This is also available from within the game menu and the game source files- 'Sources.md'

Controls.Speaker: Narrator
Controls.Dialogue: If you are stuck at any time, pressing 'H' will give you a clue for the puzzle you're stuck on. The 'J' key may provide extra information not originally shown. Try pressing 'J' whilst clicking on the poster.

Controls.Speaker: Narrator
Controls.Dialogue: If you forget what you are supposed to be doing, press the 'L' key to prompt you.

Controls.Speaker: Narrator
Controls.Dialogue: If you forget what you are supposed to be doing, press the 'L' key to prompt you. Otherwise, that's about it in terms of controls. Have fun- and I think you should interact with the door to tell your mum you're coming.

Mum_Dialogue_1.Speaker: Narrator
Mum_Dialogue_1.Dialogue: You raise your voice, as you call out to your mum, knowing she would keep yelling until you confirmed you were up.
I'm up! What did you need me for?!

Mum_Dialogue_1.Speaker: Mum
Mum_Dialogue_1.Dialogue: I have something to show you- could you get it from your bookshelf and I'll come up!
Sure! What am I looking for?

Mum_Dialogue_1.Speaker: Mum
Mum_Dialogue_1.Dialogue: It's uh, brown coloured. Looks kinda worn. The title is in cursive- just pick it up and put it on your desk!
Okay! ...a bit random to ask, but I guess I'd better find it.

Mum_Dialogue_1.Speaker: Narrator
Mum_Dialogue_1.Dialogue: You turn around from the door, and face the room, reading to look for the book.

Mum_Dialogue_2.Speaker: Narrator
Mum_Dialogue_2.Dialogue: You place the book on the desk, as your mum knocks, before entering the room.
Yeah. But I've never seen this before, Mum.

Mum_Dialogue_2.Speaker: Mum
Mum_Dialogue_2.Dialogue: That would be because I only put it there last week, thinking you'd notice.
I uh, don't really look at my bookshelf all that often.

Mum_Dialogue_2.Speaker: Mum
Mum_Dialogue_2.Dialogue: Teenagers. Anyway, it- you know what, open it. I'll show you what it does.
What it does? It's just a book-

Mum_Dialogue_3.Speaker: Narrator
Mum_Dialogue_3.Dialogue: Your hand hovers over the book as you thumb the cover, read to open it.
It's just a book... what's going to happen, it spontaneusly sets alight?

Stonewall_Dialogue.Speaker: Narrator
Stonewall_Dialogue.Dialogue: Your head aches, as you blink your eyes open for the second time today, taking a look at your surroundings, which are clearly not your room anymore.

Stonewall_Dialogue.Speaker: Narrator
Stonewall_Dialogue.Dialogue: You stand in the middle of a street, in front of you, a building covered in lights, with a sign that you can't quite make out from your current position.
What the? Mum? Where are we?

Stonewall_Dialogue.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Dialogue.Dialogue: We're... I think this is The Stonewall Inn. I remember your grandfather telling me stories- this place meant a lot to him.
The Stonewall Inn? As in, 1969 Stonewall Inn? I remember covering it in history.

Stonewall_Dialogue.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah. The book you opened? It's a bit of an heirloom. Each generation, when you're in your adulthood, you write down your name. Like a family tree.

Stonewall_Dialogue.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Dialogue.Dialogue: It's just tradition. Then, when someone further down the line opens it to a page, you usually see the memories of your most immediate relative, usually a selection of events that cause intense emotion.

Stonewall_Dialogue.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Dialogue.Dialogue: We just are. It's not back in time or anything... more like a freeze-frame in history? Have a wander about, see what you can see.
Okay... a bit weird mum, 'magic is real' or something like that... I'll deal with that particular thought process later...

Stonewall_Dialogue_Inside.Speaker: Narrator
Stonewall_Dialogue_Inside.Dialogue: As you enter the inn, you noticed that the floors are covered in shards of broken glasses, fallen stools, and an assortment of broken items.

Stonewall_Dialogue_Inside.Speaker: Narrator
Stonewall_Dialogue_Inside.Dialogue: It's vaguely dark and abandoned on the inside, as though nobody has walked through in a long time.
It's a little... messy in here. I can't imagine it was normally like this, was it Mum?

Stonewall_Dialogue_Inside.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Dialogue_Inside.Dialogue: If I had to hazard a guess, I would assume we're sometime after the Stonewall Riots, purely going off the sign outside and the condition it is in here.

Stonewall_Dialogue_Inside.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Dialogue_Inside.Dialogue: The GLF - the Gay Liberation Front - was created following Stonewall. It wasn't much after, but it was definitely following the events. Since the sign outside was for that, it helps figure the date out a bit.
I ask again, how do you just know this stuff?

Stonewall_Dialogue_Inside.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Dialogue_Inside.Dialogue: I grew up with the stories. I guess some of them stick. Anyway, take a look around. Maybe they'll be something interesting.

Stonewall_Yvonne.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Yvonne.Dialogue: This is Yvonne Ritter. I think I met her when I four, though I don't really remember it that well.
Why is she here? Or rather, why is there a picture of her?

Stonewall_Yvonne.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Yvonne.Dialogue: We're not strictly back in time. The book... well, it tends to take you to some of the most important memories of the person. The posters are representing the people- to be honest, I don't know how it works.
Well, at least it didn't take us to the moment of your birth or something... yuck.

Stonewall_Yvonne.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Yvonne.Dialogue: She's a similar age to your grandfather. She's still alive, actually, and was a pretty significant activist throughout her life.
How so? What kind of things did she do?

Stonewall_Yvonne.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Yvonne.Dialogue: She was only eighteen when Stonewall happened, it was her birthday. She was assigned male at birth you see, but was Transgender in a time where it wasn't accepted. So there was a lot of subterfuge surrounding her being who she is, because she would be persecuted otherwise.
So... what would happen if you were caught? Why was it illegal?

Stonewall_Yvonne.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Yvonne.Dialogue: It was usually imprisonment, along with some sort of criminal charge, sometimes inciting riots, things like that. In one case, it was 'female impersonation with intent to cause a crime'. In the case of Yvonne, to some degree she was lucky, they let her go after arresting her. There was no 'one box fits all' charge.
I see. Just one last question. Was the Mafia thing true?

Stonewall_Yvonne.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Yvonne.Dialogue: Yeah. It was. They would bribe the police so Stonewall could remain open. It was essentially a gap in the market, these people had nowhere to go where they were excepted, so by offering a place, they were able to capitalise on the fact they had nowhere else. Gay people, transgender people, all could dance with one another wihtout being persecuted.
That's really interesting, thank you Mum.

Stonewall_Martha.Dialogue: Is this someone also related to Stonewall?

Stonewall_Martha.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Martha.Dialogue: It's... not quite. This is... Martha Shelley I think. She wasn't involved in Stonewall itself, but in the events that followed. She was an activist and writer- she wrote
How do you remember all this stuff?

Stonewall_Martha.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Martha.Dialogue: Your grandfather was open about his past, one of the most important things he wanted me to learn was about equality. He was always open about the fact that he was bisexual. He settled down with your grandmother, but would have been just as happy if he had married a man.
I guess that makes sense. What else did Martha do?

Stonewall_Martha.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Martha.Dialogue: One of the things she was most known for, was for when she climbed on top of a fountain, a month to the day after the riot. What she did was share a message to encourage people to 'come out of the shadows and walk in the sunshine'
Oh? She seems quite important then, and it's an inspiring message for those who feel persecuted.

Stonewall_Martha.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Martha.Dialogue: She was also present at the first meeting of the Gay Liberation Front, being the one to introduce the group and give it, it's name, with each word meaning a different thing.
You really are just a fountain of knowledge, aren't you, Mum?

Stonewall_Leitsch.Dialogue: So if the other two were involved in Stonewall, was this person involved in Stonewall?

Stonewall_Leitsch.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Leitsch.Dialogue: Ah, that's Dick Leitsch. He was the leader of something called the Mattachine Society.
What's that? I remember seeing something outside that had their name on it... kind of like a Manifesto.

Stonewall_Leitsch.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Leitsch.Dialogue: The Mattachine Society as it came to be known, was one of the earliest movements regarding LGBTQ+ rights. The period of time in which they operated was known as the 'Homophile Movement'
Oh? So what was their involvement with Stonewall then?

Stonewall_Leitsch.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Leitsch.Dialogue: He was in a relationship with one of the main participants of the Stonewall Riots, someone by the name of Craig Rodwell, who owned a fairly famous bookshop by the name of the Oscar Wilde Bookshop.
So... what did Dick and Craig do then?

Stonewall_Leitsch.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Leitsch.Dialogue: They were both present at Stonewall on the nights of the event, and key to the first marches and protests regarding equal rights. Dick participated in one of the earliest acts of protest, a sit in where they would announce that they were gay, waited to be told to leave, and then sue the owners.

Stonewall_Leitsch.Speaker: Mum
Stonewall_Leitsch.Dialogue: They did a lot of other things for the LGBTQ+- in fact, it might be a little long to talk about now. But they contributed a lot, especially here in 1969, but really, all throughout the 1960's
Alright Mum, guess I'll keep looking around then.

Safe_Incorrect_TooManyDigits.Dialogue: Hmm. It seems that the safe only takes 4 numbers in its pin. I wonder if I can find the answer somewhere...

Safe_Incorrect_WrongCode.Dialogue: That seems to be the wrong pin. I wonder if it's written down somewhere.
